snippet: The study compared 25 rural Rwandan clinics that offered AIDS treatment with 25 similar clinics that did not.
abstract: Study by Brandeis University health policy analysts in The American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene finds that large donations toward fighting AIDS in poor African countries do not necessarily detract from addressing other local medical problems. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Pouring donor money into fighting AIDS in a poor African country does not necessarily detract from addressing other medical problems there, like malaria, malnutrition and infections, a six-year study in Rwanda has found. But the authors said their findings were applicable mostly to Rwanda, where a foresighted government deliberately moved to prevent a flood of donor money for AIDS from undermining other public health goals.

headline.main: Rwanda: Flood of Donations to Fight AIDS Appears Not to Detract From Other Health Issues

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: AMERICAN JOURNAL OF TROPICAL MEDICINE AND HYGIENE
